Literature Review:
The Microbiology of Biological Soil Crusts: Unveiling the Hidden World of Microorganisms in Arid Landscapes

Biological soil crusts (biocrusts) are complex communities of microorganisms that thrive on soil surfaces in arid and semi-arid regions. These communities are composed of various photosynthetic primary producers, including cyanobacteria, microalgae, and cryptogams such as lichens and mosses. The recognition of biocrusts has expanded our understanding of the microbial world in extreme environments and has opened new avenues for ecological restoration and agriculture.

The composition of biocrusts is diverse and influenced by factors such as light availability, temperature, and soil type. Studies have shown that biocrusts can harbor a wide range of microorganisms, including bacteria, archaea, fungi, and viruses (1, 2). These microorganisms play a crucial role in the biogeochemical cycles of elements such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and carbon (3, 4).

One of the key characteristics of biocrusts is their ability to alter the physical behavior of soils. For example, biocrusts can increase soil porosity, reduce soil erosion, and modify soil temperature and moisture regimes (5, 6). These changes can have significant impacts on plant growth and ecosystem function (7, 8).

The microbial communities in biocrusts are also of interest due to their potential to inform our understanding of early life on land. Studies have shown that biocrusts can harbor microorganisms that are similar to those found in ancient fossils (9). This has led to the proposal that biocrusts may have played a role in the origins of life on Earth (10).

In addition to their ecological and biogeochemical roles, biocrusts also have potential applications in agriculture and ecological restoration. For example, biocrusts can be used as a natural fertilizer and soil amendment, and can help to reduce soil erosion and improve soil health (11, 12).

Despite the growing interest in biocrusts, there is still much to be learned about these complex communities. Further research is needed to fully understand the composition, ecology, and biogeochemical roles of biocrusts in different environments.
